definition.p:
Let A and B be two non-empty sets. A function (or mapping) from the set A to the set B is an assignment of exactly one element from B each element of the set A.
We denote this by f:A\to B
If b\in B is the unique element assigned to a\in A, we write f(a)=b
We call the set A the domain of the function, and the set B the codomain of the function.

If f(a) = b, we call
b is the image of a under the mapping
a is the preimage of b under the mapping
and we define the range of the function f to be the set of images of every element in the domain, A, and often write the range by f(A). Note that the range is a subset of the codomain, f(A)\subseteq B.

note.p:
A function has two pieces of information:
Specification of two sets, the domain and codomain
A mapping between those two sets
In this class, we will be using a variety of ways of describing the domain and codomain of a function, from writing f:A \to B to describing them in words.

definition.p:
A function f is said to be injective or one-to-one if and only if f(a) = f(b) means that a = b for all a \text{ and } b in the domain of f.
f \text{ is injective means } \forall a, b ((f(a) = f(b)) \to (a = b))

note.p: To determine if a function f: A \to B is injective, we show that if f(x) = f(y) for arbitrary values x, y \in A with x \not= y, we conclude x=y. (A direct proof).
To determine if a function f: A \to B is not injective, we find particular elements x, y \in A such that x \not= y but f(x) = f(y) (a counterexample!)

statement.p:

definition.p:
A function f from A to B is said to be surjective or onto if and only if for every element b \in B, there is an element a \in A such that f(a) = B.
f \text{ is surjective means } \forall y\in B\,\, \exists x\in A \,\, ( y = f(x) )

note.p: If a function is onto, the range is exactly the codomain
To determine if a function f: A \to B is surjective, we show that given an arbitrary element y \in B we can find an element x\in A such that f(x)=y. (A direct proof).
To determine if a function f: A \to B is not surjective, we find a particular element y \in B such that f(x) \not= y for all x\in A (a counterexample!)

definition.p: A function f from A to B is said to be a one-to-one correspondance or bijective if it is both injective and surjective.

definition.p: Let f:A \to B be a bijection. The inverse function of f is the unique function that assigns to each element b\in B a unique element a \in A such that f(a) = b. We denote the inverse by f^{-1} so that f^{-1} : B \to A \text{ where } f^{-1}(b) = a \iff f(a) = b

definition.p: The floor function assigns to every real number x the largest integer that is less than or equal to x. We denote by this \lfloor x \rfloor \lfloor \cdot \rfloor : \mathbb{R}\to \mathbb{Z} \text{ with } (\lfloor x \rfloor = n) \iff (n \le x \lt n + 1)

The ceiling function assigns to every real number x the smallest integer that is greater than or equal to x. We denote by this \lceil x \rceil \lceil \cdot \rceil : \mathbb{R}\to \mathbb{Z} \text{ with } (\lceil x \rceil = n) \iff (n - 1 \lt x \le n)

definition.p: Let g:A \to B and let f:B \to C. The composition of f and g, denoted by f\circ g is defined, for all a \in A, by (f \circ g)(a) = f(g(a)).

statement.p: Suppose f and f\circ g are injective. Does it follow that g is also injective?

note.p:
Since given a function f: A \to B we define f^{-1}: B \to A by f(a) = b \iff f^{-1}(b) = a for a \in A, b \in B, we have:
for b \in B, we have (f \circ f^{-1})(b) = f(f^{-1}(b)) = f(a) = b \in B
and for a \in A, we have (f^{-1} \circ f)(a) = f^{-1}(f(a)) = f^{-1}(b) = a \in A

Let A = \{1,2,3,\ldots,10\}. Consider the function f:\pow(A) \to \N given by f(B) = |B|. That is, f takes a subset of A as an input and outputs the cardinality of that set.
Is f injective? Prove your answer.
Is f surjective? Prove your answer.
Find f\inv(1).
Find f\inv(0).
Find f\inv(12).

ol.li: f is not injective. To prove this, we must simply find two different elements of the domain which map to the same element of the codomain. Since f(\{1\}) = 1 and f(\{2\}) = 1, we see that f is not injective.
f is not surjective. The largest subset of A is A itself, and |A| = 10. So no natural number greater than 10 will ever be an output.
f\inv(1) = \{\{1\}, \{2\}, \{3\}, \ldots \{10\}\} (the set of all the singleton subsets of A).
f\inv(0) = \{\emptyset\}. Note, it would be wrong to write f\inv(0) = \emptyset - that would claim that there is no input which has 0 as an output.
f\inv(12) = \emptyset, since there are no subsets of A with cardinality 12.

statement.p:
Let A = \{n \in \N \st 0 \le n \le 999\} be the set of all numbers with three or fewer digits. Define the function f:A \to \N by f(abc) = a+b+c, where a, b, and c are the digits of the number in A. For example, f(253) = 2 + 5 + 3 = 10.
Find f\inv(3).
Find f\inv(28).
Is f injective. Explain.
Is f surjective. Explain.

ol.li: f\inv(28) = \emptyset (since the largest sum of three digits is 9+9+9 = 27)

li.p: Part (a) proves that f is not injective. The output 3 is assigned to 10 different inputs.
Part (b) proves that f is not surjective. There is an element of the codomain (28) which is not assigned to any inputs.

proof.p: Let x and y be elements of the domain \Z. Assume f(x) = f(y). If x and y are both even, then f(x) = x+1 and f(y) = y+1. Since f(x) = f(y), we have x + 1 = y + 1 which implies that x = y. Similarly, if x and y are both odd, then x - 3 = y-3 so again x = y. The only other possibility is that x is even an y is odd (or visa-versa). But then x + 1 would be odd and y - 3 would be even, so it cannot be that f(x) = f(y). Therefore if f(x) = f(y) we then have x = y, which proves that f is injective.

Let y be an element of the codomain \Z. We will show there is an element n of the domain (\Z) such that f(n) = y. There are two cases: First, if y is even, then let n = y+3. Since y is even, n is odd, so f(n) = n-3 = y+3-3 = y as desired. Second, if y is odd, then let n = y-1. Since y is odd, n is even, so f(n) = n+1 = y-1+1 = y as needed. Therefore f is surjective.

statement.p: At the end of the semester a teacher assigns letter grades to each of her students. Is this a function? If so, what sets make up the domain and codomain, and is the function injective, surjective, bijective, or neither?

solution.p: Yes, this is a function, if you choose the domain and codomain correctly. The domain will be the set of students, and the codomain will be the set of possible grades. The function is almost certainly not injective, because it is likely that two students will get the same grade. The function might be surjective it will be if there is at least one student who gets each grade.
